oracle.apps.fnd.applcore.oaext.osn.social
Class SocialObjectAsyncPublisher

java.lang.Object
  oracle.apps.fnd.applcore.oaext.osn.social.SocialObjectAsyncPublisher
All Implemented Interfaces:
OsnObjectPublisher
public final class SocialObjectAsyncPublisher
extends java.lang.Object
implements OsnObjectPublisher

The asynchronous Oracle Social Network API implemenation of a publisher. This will create a background OsnObjectPublisherThread which will asynchronously service the send requests to the Oracle Social Network APIs. This is a singleton per J2EE application. An instance of this object is obtained using getInstance() method. Resources held by the class are released by using release() method. In J2EE container, release is done by ApplCore when the App is undeployed or stopped.

Since:
11.1.1.7.0
Version:

getInstance

public static SocialObjectAsyncPublisher getInstance()
Returns and instance of BusinessActivityPublisher if one exists or creates anew one.

Returns:

osnLogin

public void osnLogin()
Login to the Oracle Social Network API. No-Op as this will be done by the asynchonronous consumer.

Specified by:
osnLogin in interface OsnObjectPublisher

sendObjectToOsn

public void sendObjectToOsn(OsnObjectAdapter osnObject)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Send the ojbect payload to Oracle Social Network. The osnObject contains the information about whether to do a insert/update or delete call to OSN. Queues the OSN Object for publishing. The queued OSN Objects are sent to the Oracle Social Network API's asynchronously.

Specified by:
sendObjectToOsn in interface OsnObjectPublisher
Parameters:
osnObject - - they payload to send to OSN.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - from underlying layer if there is an issue. Note that as this implementation simply queues the object, no exception is likely. Problems with the send will be logged by the background task and there will be no way for the user to know that an error has occured.

release

public void release()
Should be called during App undeploy to stop the publisher thread. In a J2EE container, this method is called by ApplCore ServletContextListener. Product teams should not use this method in the context of J2EE Apps.
